text: these are the children the Islamic state
group left behind stranded in a foreign
country for no crime of their own they
survived the conflict but with a
lifetime of mental scarring these kids
try to find solace in one another's
company when I first met them they
barely spoke they rarely get any visits
stigmatized my society these helpless
innocent victims are confined to this
orphanage
I've spent a few hours here and I just
can't imagine how the children have been
kept in this place for more than a year
and a half without having a chance to go
out except three or four times the place
is quite small actually only a couple of
rooms here it's hard it's suffocating
they know nothing about the outside
world faisal is now the only
psychologist rehabilitating these
children he has spent months talking to
them about their past it was mainly
through these long conversations that
the Libyans managed to identify them he
C remembers how they looked like when
they first arrived they had continuous
panic attacks they also suffered severe
insomnia and urinary incontinence they
couldn't talk and lived in isolation
Jomon eyes pen like most of the kids
here she is Egyptian she lost both her
parents and one of her two brothers in
the fight now she's left with her
younger brother smile she tells me she
misses home I have my grandmother my
grandfather and my uncle she says do you
want to see them I asked yes do you
remember your grandmother's name
she's called Aziza for months this is
what the children were caught up in as
US and British Pact forces battle to
take the city residential areas were
reduced to rubble with small heavy steps
some of the children trapped here were
desperately looking for a way out
a local photojournalist captured the
moment jimana was rescued the journalist
took us to the spot where he stood a few
meters away from the militants families
some woman were laughing and crying at
the same time the kids were lost they
were too hungry and thirsty the shelling
was around-the-clock
they were terrified some of the ladies
had no head scarves on their hair with
Missy and they smelled horrible most of
the children's wider families live here
in neighboring Egypt after weeks of
research we have managed to track down
the family of jimana and a smile their
grandparents and uncle tell me they
haven't seen them or talked to them
since they left Egypt three years ago
every time we hear a car horn we think
it's them that they've come back I feel
they might come knocking on the door any
minute
the kids will come back in a year I will
do eight but officials keep saying there
are some procedures that there is never
any progress I wanted to take a car and
go bring them back myself
but I've been told only authorities
could do so or nah I showed him a video
we filmed for the kids in Libya they
finally get a glimpse back in Libya the
children continue to wait talks to bring
them back to Egypt have stretched on for
months without an education or a future
to look forward to they don't know if
they will ever return home
Selina Beal BBC news Misrata Western
Libya
